capsules_submitted.utterance: You know, I've always been fascinated by Harry's story. He's definitely the boy who lived, and it's incredible to think about all he went through at Hogwarts. I mean, can you imagine being famous in the wizarding world from birth just because of a lightning-shaped scar on your forehead? It's no wonder he had so many challenges ahead of him.

You know, I've always been fascinated by Harry's story. He's like a symbol of hope for many people, especially in the wizarding world. The fact that he was destined to be "the boy who lived" is just incredible. It's amazing how his life was forever changed after that fateful day when Lord Voldemort tried to kill him as a baby. I mean, can you imagine being famous and feared by so many people from such a young age?
capsules_submitted.reply: that rings a bell. valeria, i remember you mentioning harry as "the boy who lived".

capsules_submitted.utterance: I've heard of Harry, he's like a legend in the wizarding world. I mean, "The Boy Who Lived" is quite an impressive title to have, especially considering what happened to him when he was just a kid. It's amazing how his story has captured people's imagination for so long.

You know, I've always been fascinated by Harry's story. He's like a symbol of hope for many people, especially in the wizarding world. The fact that he was destined to be "the boy who lived" is just incredible. It's amazing how his life was forever changed after that fateful day when Lord Voldemort tried to kill him as a baby.

I think what I find most interesting about Harry's story is the way it shows that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope for redemption and forgiveness. And let's be honest, who wouldn't want to be known as "the boy who lived"? It's like he was given a second chance at life, and he made the most of it.

But what really gets me is how Harry's experiences shaped him into the person he became. I mean, can you imagine going through all that trauma and still managing to become one of the most beloved heroes in history? It's truly inspiring, and I think we could all learn a thing or two from his example.
